00037 #ifndef __LUSTRE_HANDLES_H_
00038 #define __LUSTRE_HANDLES_H_
00039 
00045 #include <linux/rcupdate.h>
00046 #include <linux/spinlock.h>
00047 #include <libcfs/libcfs.h>
00048 
00049 struct portals_handle_ops {
00050         void (*hop_addref)(void *object);
00051         void (*hop_free)(void *object, int size);
00052 };
00053 
00054 /* These handles are most easily used by having them appear at the very top of
00055  * whatever object that you want to make handles for.  ie:
00056  *
00057  * struct ldlm_lock {
00058  *         struct portals_handle handle;
00059  *         ...
00060  * };
00061  *
00062  * Now you're able to assign the results of cookie2handle directly to an
00063  * ldlm_lock.  If it's not at the top, you'll want to use container_of()
00064  * to compute the start of the structure based on the handle field. */
00065 struct portals_handle {
00066         struct list_head                h_link;
00067         __u64                           h_cookie;
00068         const void                     *h_owner;
00069         struct portals_handle_ops      *h_ops;
00070 
00071         /* newly added fields to handle the RCU issue. -jxiong */
00072         struct rcu_head                 h_rcu;
00073         spinlock_t                      h_lock;
00074         unsigned int                    h_size:31;
00075         unsigned int                    h_in:1;
00076 };
00077 
00078 /* handles.c */
00079 
00080 /* Add a handle to the hash table */
00081 void class_handle_hash(struct portals_handle *,
00082                        struct portals_handle_ops *ops);
00083 void class_handle_unhash(struct portals_handle *);
00084 void class_handle_hash_back(struct portals_handle *);
00085 void *class_handle2object(__u64 cookie, const void *owner);
00086 void class_handle_free_cb(struct rcu_head *rcu);
00087 int class_handle_init(void);
00088 void class_handle_cleanup(void);
00089 
00092 #endif
